Message.Title: MCZ $0.46 WILL ANNOUNCE 4Q EARNINGS JUNE 6 AH....I EXPECT IT TO BE A NICE SURPRISE......COULD BE A POTENTIALLY A MULTI-BAGGER
Message.Msg: Gaming company Mad Catz (MCZ) has issued a flurry of news recently ahead of June 6, 2013 4Q and FY 2013 earnings release. Some of the new news items are very exciting and these developments may lift up this beat-up and under the radar gaming company to new highs in upcoming quarters. The most recent (yesterday AH) was the announcement of a new CFO. 4Q 2013 . Here are some interesting developments: Mad Catz making Xbox One products May 28, 2013 8:49AM PDT Eddie Makuch By Eddie Makuch, News Editor Peripheral company Mad Catz confirms it is working on a "range" of official products for next-gen Xbox; more details to be shared at E3. Peripheral company Mad Catz is making a "range" of official products for Microsoft's Xbox One, the company announced today. Mad Catz did not go into detail regarding the nature of these products, but said more information will be provided next month at the 2013 Electronic Entertainment Expo. "We are eagerly looking forward to the upcoming launch of the Xbox One and excited about the opportunity to develop a range of innovative products to support the platform," Mad Catz president and CEO Darren Richardson said in a statement This is just the tip of the iceberg (check out these recent developments): Recent Sony news Recent Smart TV news Recent headset bundle news An analyst expects revenues to double YoY ......Not bad for a company turning profitable and trading at a huge discount (0.2 X Sales)

Topic.Title: Country wide BK

Message.Msg: Agreed. If they were going to do it, it should have been done a long time ago. Even then it would be a very long, very messy process as BAC would be challenged on any claim that they have no successor liability, which is basically what a bankruptcy would be all about. Unfortunately, it would also further damage the bank's reputation. For a bank to take the bankruptcy route, even for a subsidiary, is a step no bank every takes lightly. Not even Citi, with it's good bank / bad bank, has taken that route with it's bad loans. It would be hard to measure what sort of damage would be done to the stock price since this is something that simply has no precedent that I'm aware of.

Topic.Title: AIG will get NOTHING!

Message.Msg: Which lawsuit are you referring to? Remember, the current court hearing is NOT a lawsuit by AIG but they are objecting to a previous settlement. If you are referring to the $10 billion (I think it is) lawsuit AIG is trying to bring against BAC, I hope you're correct. In that case a lot will hinge on how much weight is given to the Feds having told BAC that they wouldn't be liable for any of the stuff the Feds bought from AIG. It's that very liability that AIG is trying to sue BAC for. There may be others, but they all sort of run together after awhile.

Message.Title: Why doesn't BofA let Countrywide go BK?
Message.Msg: In a Seeking Alpha note today: [Day 2 of Bank of America's (BAC) Article 77 hearing led off with a new revelation: Chief Risk Officer Terry Laughlin in Nov. 2011 told the 22 institutional investors in favor of the settlement the bank had been given permission to put Countrywide into bankruptcy if the mortgage lender's liabilities threatened the BofA's viability - the message clearly being the $8.5B settlement was a pretty good outcome for those suffering losses. Naturally, the "objectors" say there were other options rather than signing off on a "sweetheart deal."] So you might ask why BofA didn't just allow Countrywide to go BK and save the shareholders $40 Billion? The reason why is that the ramifications would be far worse. It would freeze up the housing market and stop the improvement in home values in its tracks. It would force a jump in mortgage rates. It would lose a good portion of the goodwill that BofA enjoys. And it would be a serious drop in the future asset value of BofA. This means that BofA is in a corner and cannot get out without losing, at least partially, the court cases brought by AIG. And that explains why BAC is down on the day and will probably continue to drop until after BofA finishes wading through all this muck and swamp and can reach higher land. It will eventually.

Topic.Title: What is the 60 billion lawsuit again BOA

Message.Msg: It is the $8.5 billion settlement that AIG is opposing in court today. If these go bad for BAC and the settlement is tossed out then BAC could owe AIG and others up to $60 billion. Do not worry it is almost impossible to happen but if this is a really bad judge then we could get stuck with paying $20 billion. Remember 90% of those who had mbs losses agreed to the $8.5 billion settlement, except AIG and a few others. This judge ONLY needs to say the settlement was done in reasonable fairness.

Topic.Title: What is the 60 billion lawsuit again BOA

Message.Msg: There isn't a single 60 billion lawsuit. They were either referring to the original amounts that was being sought until the $8.5 billion settlement was agreed upon, or they could be referring to the total liability BAC has for all legal issues in total, or to what their future liability could be for suits still open or coming up.

Message.Title: AIG Too Greedy
Message.Msg: The problem with AIG is that they don't know when to stop. What they will wind up doing is forcing BAC to take the final step and bankrupt Countrywide, then everyone loses. BAC, for whatever reason, has been trying to do the right thing for all the hurt parties, while keeping the integrity of the bank. The amounts AIG is seeking could put the integrity of the bank at risk, and BAC can't allow that to happen. Putting Countrywide into bankruptcy will be a long and messy battle with no winners. AIG doesn't seem to realize that, or maybe they do. I can guarantee that AIG isn't making any friends on Wall Street with their extravagant demands. Will they see the light before it's too late?

Topic.Title: AIG Too Greedy

Message.Msg: Actually, successor liability has not been determined in the courts, although some rulings seem to favor the idea that BAC doesn't have it. That's why any bankruptcy would be long and messy. When BAC bought CFC, they specifically did the merger in a manner to fence CFC from the rest of the bank for just such an event. Even the Feds and banking regulators understand that the bank isn't a bottomless pot of money. There will come a point when the Feds will either have to intervene or face the real prospect of testing the too big to fail policies they've put in place. I very much doubt they want to go that route, but both AIG and Schneiderman could back everyone into a corner. In a case like that I can almost guarantee it will cause an economic crisis even worse that what we've been through.

Message.Title: Good buy at $13 - market will go up soon
Message.Msg: The overall market is taking a breather because of profit taking but its direction is up - it will be over 18,000 by 2015 and 20,000 by 2017. 1. Valuation - FPE for DJIA is just 15 - markets usually peak at 20+. 2. Corporate earnings and balance sheets are very strong. 3. Bond bubble is finally bursting and some of that money will end up in equities. 4. Rotation from defensive to industrial/financial stocks is in progress and will continue. 5. Fed will reduce asset purchases but unwinding of QE will be done over several years - fears of QE are overstated. 6. Low interest rates/low inflation are ideal for stocks. They will remain low for the foreseeable future. 7. M&A will heat up as recovery continues, albeit at slow pace. 8. Recent decline in budget deficit from CBO estimates is very positive. The current deficit is at 4% of GDP but the trajectory shows it would soon end up at 2% of GDP which is not excessive. 9. Europe is stabilizing and in 2014 will give a big boost to world trade - recent austerity, while painful in the near-term, will be positive going forward. 10. Japan is showing sign of growth and other Asian countries will follow.

Topic.Title: AIG Too Greedy

Message.Msg: I think I did answer. BAC didn't bankrupt CFC because they knew it would be a long drawn out legal nightmare and the bank probably couldn't have survived as well back then. It would have also been a major blow to their already sullied reputation since it would basically have left bondholders out in the cold. I can't even begin to guess how the bond markets would punish BAC bonds in that sort of scenario. We are not talking about some simple bankruptcy. This is extremely complex, touches many different and potentially conflicting laws, both state and federal. In short, BAC chose to deal with the lesser nightmare of paying out a few billion than a situation in which they had no guarantee if they could even survive it.
